feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued November 22 at 3:06AM EST until November 22 at 4:15AM EST by NWS Jackson KY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...A portion of east central Kentucky, including the following counties, Bath, Fleming, Montgomery and Rowan.
* WHEN...Until 415 AM EST.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 306 AM EST, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the advisory area. Between 1 and 1.2 inches of rain have fallen. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Mount Sterling, Morehead, Flemingsburg, Owingsville, Sharpsburg, Grange City, Wyoming, Hillsboro, Oakley, Ringos Mills, Pebble, Odessa, Slate Valley, Peasticks, Craigs, Poplar Plains, Moore's Ferry, Sharkey, Tilton and Goddard.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Bath, KY; Fleming, KY; Montgomery, KY; Rowan, KY

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 415 AM EST EARLY THIS MORNING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 22 at 3:05AM EST by NWS Burlington VT
entry.summary: Across Vermont early this morning, wet roads combined with temperatures falling below freezing may result in some patchy black ice this morning. Motorists and pedestrians should exercise caution as paved surfaces that appear wet may, in fact, be icy.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Grand Isle; Western Franklin; Orleans; Essex; Western Chittenden; Lamoille; Caledonia; Washington; Western Addison; Orange; Western Rutland; Eastern Franklin; Eastern Chittenden; Eastern Addison; Eastern Rutland; Western Windsor; Eastern Windsor

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 22 at 3:05AM EST by NWS Burlington VT
entry.summary: Across northern New York early this morning, wet roads combined with temperatures falling below freezing may result in some patchy black ice this morning. Motorists and pedestrians should exercise caution as paved surfaces that appear wet may, in fact, be icy.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northern St. Lawrence; Northern Franklin; Eastern Clinton; Southeastern St. Lawrence; Southern Franklin; Western Clinton; Western Essex; Eastern Essex; Southwestern St. Lawrence

entry.title: Flood Warning issued November 22 at 3:05AM EST until November 22 at 6:15AM EST by NWS Jackson KY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of east central Kentucky, including the following counties, Bath, Menifee and Montgomery.
* WHEN...Until 615 AM EST.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 305 AM EST, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. Flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the warned area. Between 0.7 and 1 inch of rain has fallen. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Mount Sterling, Jeffersonville, Camargo, Upper Spencer, Lower Spencer, Oggs Station, Coons Station, Howards Mill, Walkers Crossing, Gatewoods Station, Peeled Oak, Lucky Stop, Stepstone, Hope, Ewington, Clay Lick, Crooks, Levee, Kendall Springs and Cedar Groves.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Bath, KY; Menifee, KY; Montgomery, KY

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL 615 AM EST THIS MORNING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 22 at 12:48AM MST by NWS Goodland KS
entry.summary: Dense fog has formed over Norton county. Use extra caution when traveling this morning as visibilities will be reduced to less than a quarter mile at times.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Norton

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 22 at 2:48AM EST by NWS Jackson KY
entry.summary:
At 248 AM EST, Doppler radar was tracking a cluster of strong thunderstorms along a line extending from Hope to near Bean to near Virden to Harris Ferry. Movement was east at 55 mph.
HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 40 mph.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects.
Locations impacted include... Mount Sterling, Stanton, Frenchburg, Jeffersonville, Camargo, Clay City, Campsites in the Indian Creek area of the Daniel Boone National Forrest, Clay Lick, Levee, Bowen, Cornwell, Kimbrell, Rothwell, Olympia Springs, Yale, Fagan, Bangor, Virden, Prewitt, and Vaughns Mill.
THIS INCLUDES Bert T. Combs Mountain Parkway between mile markers 12 and 35.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Montgomery; Bath; Rowan; Estill; Powell; Menifee; Morgan

cap:parameter.value: STRONG THUNDERSTORMS WILL IMPACT POWELL...SOUTHERN MONTGOMERY... NORTHWESTERN MORGAN...SOUTHEASTERN BATH...NORTHWESTERN ESTILL... MENIFEE AND SOUTHEASTERN ROWAN COUNTIES THROUGH 315 AM EST

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued November 22 at 1:41AM CST until November 22 at 4:00AM CST by NWS Louisville KY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...Portions of south central Indiana, including the following county, Perry and central Kentucky, including the following counties, Breckinridge, Grayson, Hancock, Meade and Ohio.
* WHEN...Until 400 AM CST /500 AM EST/.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 141 AM CST /241 AM EST/, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the advisory area. Between 0.5 and 1 inch of rain has fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts of 0.5 to 1 inch are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Hardinsburg, Irvington, Cloverport, Fordsville, Mcquady, Kirk, Tar Fork, Mattingly, Glen Dean and Axtel. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 22 at 1:34AM CST by NWS Louisville KY
entry.summary:
At 133 AM CST, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 8 miles north of Portland, moving east at 45 mph.
HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 50 mph and pea size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Minor hail damage to vegetation is possible.
Locations impacted include... Scottsville, Franklin, Fountain Run, Oak Forest, Black Jack, West Fork, Maynard, Clare, Geddes, and Mcelroy Ford.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Simpson; Allen; Barren; Monroe

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 22 at 2:27AM EST by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
Locally dense fog expected early this morning across inland Northeast Florida and inland Southeast Georgia, mainly along the I-10 and I-75 corridors, with visibilities around 1/4 mile or less in some locations.
The nature of the fog is such that visibilities will vary greatly over short distances. Motorists should be alert for rapidly changing conditions through sunrise.

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued November 22 at 1:17AM CST by NWS Topeka KS
entry.summary:
ESFTOP
A Hydrologic Outlook is no longer in effect for the...
Neosho River Near Neosho Rapids
Flooding is not expected as the river is forecast to crest near 18 feet Saturday morning, roughly 4 feet below flood stage.
Additional weather and stream information is available at www.weather.gov/top/.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lyon, KS

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 22 at 2:01AM EST by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
Satellite imagery and traffic cameras show patchy dense fog has developed across portions of Orange, Osceola, Brevard, Indian River, St. Lucie and Okeechobee counties. Fog will produce localized visibilities below a half mile in spots. Motorists should be prepared for sudden changes in visibility.
If encountering dense fog on area roadways, use your low beam headlights, reduce your speed, and maintain a safe distance between your vehicle and the one ahead of you.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Orange; Osceola; Okeechobee; Coastal Indian River; Coastal St. Lucie; Inland Northern Brevard; Inland Indian River; Inland St. Lucie; Mainland Northern Brevard; Northern Brevard Barrier Islands; Inland Southern Brevard; Mainland Southern Brevard; Southern Brevard Barrier Islands

entry.title: Rip Current Statement issued November 22 at 3:37PM ChST until November 25 at 6:00AM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents.
* WHERE...East facing reefs of the Marianas.
* WHEN...Through late Monday night.
* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Elevated easterly trade swell will maintain a high risk of rip currents along east facing reefs of the Marianas through at least late Monday night. Although the primary swell energy is focused out of the east, surf is expected to hover just below hazardous criteria along north facing reefs of the Marianas, so caution is advised for those venturing out to the beaches the next several days.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Guam; Rota; Tinian; Saipan

cap:parameter.value: HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH LATE MONDAY NIGHT

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued November 22 at 2:32PM ChST until November 24 at 3:00PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Hazardous surf of 7 to 9 feet.
* WHERE...North and east facing reefs of Kosrae. North facing reefs of Pohnpei.
* WHEN...Until 3 PM ChST Monday.
* IMPACTS...Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Hazardous surf conditions will continue through Monday afternoon, possibly longer as a persistent north swell will keep surf elevated.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kosrae; Pohnpei

cap:parameter.value: HIGH SURF ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 3 PM CHST MONDAY

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued November 21 at 8:31PM PST until November 23 at 10:00PM PST by NWS Eureka CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Increased threat of sneaker waves expected.
* WHERE...Coastal Del Norte, Northern Humboldt Coast, Southwestern Humboldt and Mendocino Coast Counties.
* WHEN...From 1 AM PST Saturday through Sunday evening. .
* IMPACTS...Large, unexpected waves can sweep across the beach without warning, sweeping people into the sea from rocks, jetties, and beaches. These sneaker waves can also move large objects such as logs, crushing anyone caught underneath.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coastal Del Norte; Northern Humboldt Coast; Southwestern Humboldt; Mendocino Coast

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT IN EFFECT FROM 1 AM PST SATURDAY THROUGH SUNDAY EVENING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 21 at 10:44PM EST by NWS Wakefield VA
entry.summary:
Areas of fog have developed across Northeast North Carolina late this evening. Visibility will generally be one half to one mile, but fog will be locally dense with visibility reduced to one quarter mile or less. Fog will persist overnight, before lifting toward sunrise as a warm front lifts north of the area.
Motorists should be alert for sudden changes in visibility due to the fog. Drive at reduced speeds and use low beam headlights only.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northampton; Hertford; Gates; Pasquotank; Camden; Western Currituck; Bertie; Chowan; Perquimans; Eastern Currituck

cap:parameter.value: AREAS OF FOG ACROSS NORTHEAST NORTH CAROLINA TONIGHT

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 21 at 10:40PM EST by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
entry.summary: Areas of fog, dense at times, is expected to persist through tonight across eastern North Carolina. Visibilities could reach one quarter mile or less at times. Fog is expected to dissipate early Saturday morning. If you need to travel, turn on your low beam headlights when approaching fog, drive slowly, and keep your distance from other vehicles.

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued November 21 at 6:12PM PST until November 24 at 10:00PM PST by NWS San Francisco CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...A long period northwesterly swell will result in an increased risk for sneaker waves and rip currents. Breaking waves of 13 to 18 feet are expected.
* WHERE...Pacific Coast beaches.
* WHEN...Through Monday evening.
* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can unexpectedly run significantly farther up the beach than normal, including over rocks and jetties. Rip currents are typically more frequent and stronger in the vicinity of jetties, inlets, and piers.
entry.cap:areaDesc: San Francisco; Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes National Seashore; San Francisco Peninsula Coast; Northern Monterey Bay; Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued November 21 at 3:24PM AKST until November 22 at 9:00AM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow and blowing snow. Up to 2 inches of snowfall combined with winds gusting up to 40 mph will result in blowing snow and reduced visibilities down to one half mile at times.
* WHERE...Kuskokwim Delta Coast and Nunivak Island.
* WHEN...Until 9 AM AKST Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Visibilities reduced to one half mile or less due to blowing snow. Travel could be very difficult. Areas of blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Blowing snow is expected primarily along the coast from Toksook Bay to Kipnuk where winds will be strongest. Antecedent snowpack may work locally to exaggerate blowing snow impacts. Worst conditions closest to the coast from 9pm to midnight tonight.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kuskokwim Delta Coast and Nunivak Island

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 9 AM AKST SATURDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 21 at 6:59PM EST by NWS Caribou ME
entry.summary:
Wet roads will gradually refreeze tonight, leading to icy conditions. Be prepared for black ice, especially over northern Aroostook County.
Motorists and pedestrians are advised to take extra caution due to slippery conditions on roadways and sidewalks.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northwest Aroostook; Northeast Aroostook; Northern Somerset; Northern Piscataquis; Northern Penobscot; Southeast Aroostook

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 21 at 2:06PM AKST by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
Snow showers have begun across the central and eastern Interior. Circle Hot Springs reported a quick 2.4 inches through 9am Friday morning, and 3.0 inches was reported at Chicken. Heavier snow bands embedded within this system will lead to widely varying snow totals across the region. Snow will taper off Saturday night and Sunday.
South of the Chatanika River, expect around 2 to 4 inches of snow, including in Fairbanks. In Fairbanks, there is a 30% chance for 4-6+ inches as the heaviest is only about 30 miles northeast. This would only be possible if the localized heavier banding moves overhead, which is possible.
The heaviest snow near Fairbanks will be in the hills off of Chena Hot Springs Road where 4 to 7 inches are expected. Expect 3 to 6 inches in the White Mountains National Recreation Area and heavier amounts up to 12 inches north and east of Eagle Summit.
From Manley Hot Springs to Bettles, expect 1 to 3 inches with lesser amounts to the west.
From Nenana to Denali Park and Cantwell, expect 2 to 3 inches.
Expect 1 to 3 inches around Delta Junction, but up to 8 inches along the Richardson Highway near Trims Camp.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Dalton Highway Summits; Delta Junction; Tanana Flats; Eielson AFB and Salcha; Goldstream Valley and Nenana Hills; Two Rivers; Fairbanks Metro Area; Nenana; Central Interior; Northern Denali Borough; Southern Denali Borough; Eastern Alaska Range North of Trims Camp; Eastern Alaska Range South of Trims Camp

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued November 21 at 2:29PM PST until November 24 at 3:00AM PST by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Large breaking waves of 12 to 16 feet with dangerous rip currents.
* WHERE...San Luis Obispo County Beaches and Santa Barbara County Central Coast Beaches.
* WHEN...Until 3 AM PST Monday.
* IMPACTS...There is an increased risk of ocean drowning. Rip currents can pull swimmers and surfers out to sea. Large breaking waves can cause injury, wash people off beaches and rocks, and capsize small boats near shore. Minor beach erosion and minor flooding of usually dry areas may occur.
entry.cap:areaDesc: San Luis Obispo County Beaches; Santa Barbara County Central Coast Beaches

cap:parameter.value: HIGH SURF ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 3 AM PST MONDAY

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued November 21 at 2:02PM PST until November 24 at 4:00AM PST by NWS Portland OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Sneaker waves possible.
* WHERE...North and Central Coast of Oregon, and South Washington Coast.
* WHEN...Through late Sunday night.
* IMPACTS...Waves can run up significantly farther on a beach than normal, including over rocks and jetties. Sneaker waves can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly pull them into the frigid ocean which may lead to serious injury or drowning.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A Beach Hazards Statement is issued when sneaker waves create potentially life-threatening conditions in the surf zone. Caution should be used when in or near the water. Always keep an eye on the waves, and be especially watchful of children. Those participating in razor clam digs should exercise caution.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Clatsop County Coast; Tillamook County Coast; Central Coast of Oregon; South Washington Coast

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH LATE SUNDAY NIGHT

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued November 21 at 5:29AM AKST until November 22 at 6:00AM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 4 to 10 inches. Winds gusting as high as 35 mph in southern Kachemak Bay.
* WHERE...SW Kenai Peninsula and Southern Kachemak Bay.
* WHEN...Until 6 AM AKST Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. The hazardous conditions could impact the Friday morning and evening commutes. Expect icy conditions to develop throughout the day as wet roadways freeze and snow accumulates.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A gradually cooling airmass will transition rain to heavy wet snow this morning. Highest snow accumulations expected along higher elevations such as Dimond Ridge, Nikolaevsk and along Jakolof Bay Rd in southern Kachemak Bay.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Southern Kachemak Bay; SW Kenai Peninsula

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 AM AKST SATURDAY
